Movie: The Secret Life of Walter Mitty

Review: My almost humiliating desperation to watch and make art that speaks as loudly as this has never wavered. I’ve written about Kiarostami a lot, words that I keep to myself, words that almost keep my heart beating. I’ve described his filmography as being “a home i could run to — a warm hug, a cup of tea, a date tree”. However, in many ways, Homework evades this description. It is a home I feel every emotion towards; it portrays the…

i just told gus this reminded me of that scene in asteroid city, and so i have to say that here as well. i think it’s really special when people are able to create something so emotionally loud with so little physical equipment. the awe the characters feel is so evident and is extended to the audience. gus this is amazing, with a whole crew behind you i can’t begin to imagine what you’ll do next.

really poignant and thoughtful. for me, as a writer who is seemingly able to do anything but write, this stings. this encapsulates how i feel about writing, having to constantly reinvent what ‘good enough’ means, and where my standards lie. that makes it really special to me. my future classmates are so talented, giancarl this was beautiful!

Review: the most profound viewing experience i’ve had since watching where is the friend’s home for the first time. i’ve seen this movie no less than 10 times, and i don’t recall ever being this moved by it. an in-class screening, and i bawled my way through it. poignant, lingering, i am equally excited and horrified by the coming of age.

Review: making art - or trying to make art - is best described as being draining, and you can see that here. where do you stop, how do you start and when is it good enough? can it ever be good enough? 5 years after the release of make happy, bo releases his fourth comedy special on netflix, inside, and it’s phenomenal, unhinged and exhausting. i wrote a review on art is dead and this whole thing feels like bo cementing…

“you’re everything you hated, are you happy?”an 18-year-old bo burnham writes and performs his first, hour-long comedy special, words words words. there’s a lot that can be explored with this special, burnham’s wordplay is an endless rabbit hole of satire. while it doesn’t seem as strong as his two specials that followed just a few years later, there is a clear stand-out song. art is dead is his magnum opus. so early on in his career, and at such…

Movie: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan

Review: I love how Bergman displays purpose through his work. It all feels important, his unique portrayal of faith is something that I talked about in my review of The Seventh Seal, but in Winter Light he peels back another layer of the same puzzle and allows us to ponder and dive deeper into these ideas. We meet Tomas, a man living in a newly formed sense of absence in his faith as he desperately tries to find his way back.…

“She looks like she did in 1962 and I look like this.”Naturalistic, sober, and sincere. 45 Years defines the harsh reality of the passage of time, as it plays perhaps the most vital role in this film. The marked out days reminiscent of a countdown, an indication of the deterioration of communication between Kate and Geoff. Gradual increase of silence, as the maze of growing older together grows more and more paths that lead nowhere. Haigh classifies time as…

Anger and frustration are fastidious in their portrayal in Marriage Story, and evidently present during the argument scene. Baumbach continuously builds a feeling of pressure throughout the whole film, in courtrooms and both characters’ homes, and all that restrained emotion begins to let loose in the duration of this one scene. It’s incredibly effective as it reinforces our place as merely the viewer, and is one of the most emotionally impactful and exhausting scenes I’ve seen."It’s only that night.…

Movie: Folklore: The Long Pond Studio Sessions

Review: The Seventh Seal holds as much power when it comes to absurdism as works like Waiting For Godot, both of which pose questions we cannot comprehend. The Seventh Seal takes a different route, though. Using surrealist aspects to display religious beliefs of death on screen, a hooded figure plays death as he challenges a man soon to die to a game of chess. By taking these ideas literally, and facing death as it is thought to be, the film becomes…

Movie: American Murder: The Family Next Door

Review: Blood. The scarlet liquid that colors Carrie White’s life. It rains from the ceiling and onto her once pink gown, now soaked in pigs blood. Her hair drenched, now painted with that metallic-tasting liquid. The smell of coins that now lives on her hands and feet and smeared all over her face, with only two dots of green fighting their way through the crimson. Death has its hands on Carrie White, but it’ll take much more before it takes her.…

The poignant smell of smoke jumps through the screen, leftover ash and unused machinery clutter the land, everything here looks the same: vile and hellish. Mountains of trash and dirt populate the streets with memories of what could have been hidden deep between them. The sounds are inescapable for Henry, every turn leads him to a more provoking, piping noise. Henry doesn’t understand much about what’s going on around him. The "food" is not much but a rotting carcass, spouting…
